SITE_DESC: This site is located at a working farm in County Tyrone, and is one of three COSMOS-UK sites situated in Northern Ireland. The arable field in which the COSMOS-UK site is located slopes gently to the south.

The Heytesbury COSMOS-UK site is based on an active MOD site in Wiltshire. The hilly region is an expanse of fields and small patches of woodland. The site is situated on exposed grassland with compact limestone and flint soil.

This site is located on the working Wimpole Estate. The National Trust site hosts parkland, gardens, and the farm where nature-friendly farming methods aim to benefit local biodiversity. The COSMOS-UK site is situated in an arable field on clay to clayey loam soils.

This site is located on the East Anglian Fens near Ely, situated on a grass strip between two arable fields growing a variety of crops, including maize, on peat soils. This COSMOS-UK site ceased operation in 2018.

LOCATION_SOURCE: Site Info sheet on P drive
SITE_DESC: The Riseholme site is based at Riseholme College Agricultural Centre in Lincoln, a centre for vocational excellence in agriculture. The COSMOS-UK site is located in a livestock grazed grass field, on calcareous mineral soil.

Located in the grounds of Rothamsted Research at Harpenden in Hertfordshire, a site of agricultural research since 1843, and the site of long term and innovative hydrometeorological measurement. Current research at Rothamsted addresses all aspects of arable agriculture. It is a flat site with well-drained or moderately well-drained clayey loam soil.

The site hosted by the Sheepdrove Organic Farm and Conference Centre is located in the rolling grasslands of the Berkshire Downs. The farm is run on strict organic standards to protect wildlife and the environment. No chemical fertilisers are used; instead organic matter such as compost or manure are added and as a result the soil contains a high organic matter content than might be expected on a chalk downland. The field in which the COSMOS-UK site is located was converted from grassland to arable in 2019. The site is co-located with eddy covariance flux monitoring equipment.
The Stoughton site is on an arable farm owned by Farmcare. The site is flat with loam to clayey loam soils.

This site is located in the Stiperstones National Nature Reserve in south Shropshire. This includes a major part of the Stiperstones ridge and has geology of national significance due to the Ordovician 'Stiperstones Quartzite'. The COSMOS-UK site is situated on a slightly sloping rough grassland, acid/ heathland grazed by livestock. The soil is an organic soil with some mineral material, resulting in high moisture content, high soil organic carbon and low bulk density.

STANDARD_LAYOUT: Raised instruments. Pluvio aperture height and CRNS horizontal heigh approx. 1.7m and 1.1m.
SITE_DESC: This site on a peat-based moor is located in the area generally known as the Somerset Levels. The moor is a very flat landscape only very slightly above sea-level, and is prone to flooding. Water is managed via a series of drains and sluices. Because of its importance as a wetland, the site is designated as a Site of Special Scientific Interest (Tealham and Tadham Moors SSSI) and a RAMSAR site. The land use is grassland, occasionally grazed. The site is co-located with eddy covariance flux monitoring equipment.

This site located in a loop of the River Thames 5km north west of Oxford on an estate owned by the University of Oxford. The woodlands are a designated SSSI and also host an ECN and FLUXNET monitoring site. The COSMOS-UK ceased operation in 2016.

Spen Farm together with Headley Hall and Wise Warren are the three farms that comprise the University of Leeds Research Farm. Spen Farm houses the The National Pig Centre, part of the Centre for Innovation Excellence in Livestock (CIEL). The COSMOS-UK site is on the boundary between two large fields on Headley Hall Farm which is part of the University of Leeds' 'Smart farm' research programme. The site is co-located with a Met Office monitoring site.

The site is hosted by Moreton Morrell College which has a 300 ha site in Warwickshire. Two-thirds of the site is operated as a commercial farm that also teaches students modern farming techniques including precision agriculture. The site is located in a flat area of improved grassland.

This site is based on the Writtle University College farm site in Writtle, Essex. The COSMOS-UK site is situated between fields of rough and livestock-grazed grassland. The soil is stoney London clay, the typical mineral soil of the area.

STANDARD_LAYOUT: Forest flux tower. Platform height 26m. MetPak height 27m.
SITE_DESC: This is one of the few COSMOS-UK sites located in woodland; in this case the Alice Holt Forest managed by the Forestry Commission and situated in the South Downs National Park. Alice Holt is also one of the main research stations of Forest Research. The COSMOS-UK instrumentation is co-located with monitoring equipment operated by Forest Research that contributes to FLUXNET and the Environmental Change Network, in an area of broadleaf trees and scrub.

The James Hutton Institute Balruddery Research Farm is a 170 ha arable farm located seven miles west of Dundee and on the lower slopes of the Sidlaw Hills. The soil is a sandy loam, slightly shallow in depth towards Balruddery Den towards the southwest margin of the CRNS footprint. The farm site includes the Centre for Sustainable Cropping Platform which provides a whole systems framework for designing and testing cropping systems.
BEDROCK_CLASS: SANDSTONE WITH SUBORDINATE CONGLOMERATE, SILTSTONE AND MUDSTONE

SITE_DESC: Bunny Park (160 ha) is part of the University of Nottingham Farm comprising a range of arable, woodland and grassland land cover types. The COSMOS-UK site is flat, surrounded by arable crops on sandy to sandy loam soils.

Chobham Common is one of the finest examples of a lowland heath in the world and contains a wide range of habitats and rare biodiversity. Heathland is an ancient and characteristic British landscape that was in fact created by prehistoric farmers, and managed down the generations providing a living link to our stone-age past. Soils are highly variable in thickness and texture from sand to coarse gravel.

Easter Bush is located to the south of Edinburgh, close to the UKCEH Edinburgh site on the Bush Estate at Penicuik. It is co-located with an eddy covariance flux monitoring site. It is a grassland site with a typical loamy mineral soil.
BEDROCK_CLASS: SEDIMENTARY ROCK CYCLES, STRATHCLYDE GROUP TYPE

SITE_DESC: This site is located at the CAFRE (College of Agriculture, Food and Rural Enterprise) Hill Farm Centre in Glenwherry, midway between Ballymena and Larne. The ~1000 ha farm comprises 100 suckler cows and 1100 breeding ewes and strives to demonstrate effective integration of livestock and environmental management. The soils near the COSMOS-UK site have very high organic carbon and low bulk density.

LOCATION_SOURCE: Site Info sheet on P drive
SITE_DESC: The Henfaes Research Centre is the main field facility of Bangor University's School of Environment, Natural Resources and Geography. The COSMOS-UK site is located in an upland area that is operated as a commercial sheep unit within the Centre for Hill and Upland Management. The site is situated on silty mineral soils with a high organic matter content.

The site is located on the south west edge of the Moor House Upper Teesdale National Nature Reserve on a site that drains to the River Eden to the west rather than the River Tees to the east. The mineral loamy soil has a high organic content and supports cotton grass and heather.
BEDROCK_CLASS: LIMESTONE WITH SUBORDINATE SANDSTONE AND ARGILLACEOUS ROCKS

SITE_DESC: This site is a Rothamsted Research farm where scientists investigate the impact of agriculture on the land and atmosphere. The field where the COSMOS-UK site is located was a grassland with grazing livestock until 2019. Since then it has been used for arable crop production.

LOCATION_SOURCE: Site Info sheet on P drive
SITE_DESC: This site is located on a south facing slope among the vines on the Redhill Estate near Wateringbury in Kent. The soil is slightly calcareous with a sand to sandy loam texture.

The Sourhope site is located in the Scottish borders just over 1 km from the border with England. The site is on a south facing slope on the western side of The Cheviot Hills. The site is on an area of rough grassland in the headwaters of Beaumont Water.

This is a gentle sloping grassland site with deep clay/loam soil. It is close to Aylesbury in Buckinghamshire and within the estate of Waddesdon Manor. Two eddy covariance flux monitoring sites are located nearby.

Fincham is a privately owned farm and food processing plant in northwest Norfolk. The COSMOS-UK site is situated in a large, flat arable crop field with winter wheat, oil seed rape and sugar beet on 6 year rotation. The soil type is chalky loam, a calcareous mineral soil.

STANDARD_LAYOUT: Site orientated 30degrees. See CSL completion report.
SITE_DESC: This site is located in an 'Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty' on a working farm in West Dorset. The 1034 ha organic farm hosts livestock, rare flora and fauna, ancient woodland, and bodies of water. The COSMOS-UK site is situated in an arable field next to a grazed grassland, on typical mineral soils.

STANDARD_LAYOUT: Site orientation 344degrees. Aligned with fence at farmers request
SITE_DESC: The Cochno Farm and Research Centre is part of the University of Glasgow's Scottish Centre for Production Animal Health and Food Safety. To the north east of city, the site is south facing grassland with clayey loam to sandy loam soils. The COSMOS-UK site ceased operation in 2020.

Bickley Hall Farm is an organic working farm in the heart of run by the Cheshire Wildlife Trust. The wildlife-friendly farm management regime is supported by Natural England's Countryside Stewardship Scheme to maintain species-rich hay meadows and pastures. Soils are sands and sandy loams.

The Cardington site is based on the Met Office Meteorological Research Unit at the Cardington Air Field, Bedfordshire. The facility has a wide variety of research-grade surface, sub-surface, mast-mounted, and balloon-borne instruments. The COSMOS-UK site is located on flat maintained grassland on typical mineral soil of clayey to sandy loam.

The Cwm Garw site is on a working farm on the southern side of the Preseli Mountains in Pembrokeshire. The field in which the COSMOS-UK site is located is a grazed grassland on loam to clay soils. The site is co-located with BGS monitoring equipment.

Chimney Meadows is the Berks, Bucks & Oxon Wildlife Trust's largest nature reserve in Oxfordshire. Part of the site is a National Nature Reserve (owned by Natural England). These wildflower meadows make up one of England's largest remaining areas of unspoilt grassland. The site often floods during winter.

Cockle Park Farm is a 262 ha working farm owned by Newcastle University and located to the north of Morpeth in Northumberland. The farm links farming practice, landscape management and rural enterprise with cutting edge interdisciplinary research in agriculture. The COSMOS-UK site is located in the centre of a field that slopes gently down to the River Lyne. This area of the farm is used for growing cereals and oilseeds.

The Crichton Royal farm is located south of Dumfries and operated by Scotland's Rural College, SRUC as its Dairy Research Centre. It is a grassland site that slopes gently to the south west on soils that are clayey loams to sandy loams.

This site is located at Agroco Farms, a working farm to the north-west of Ipswich. The COSMOS-UK site is situated on a strip of grassland running between arable and horticultural fields. Soils in the area are locally chalky, generally loam to clayey loam.
SOIL_TEXTURE: LOAM TO CLAYEY LOAM, LOCALLY CHALKY

SITE_DESC: The site is hosted by Euston Estate which comprises a mixture of farmland and woodland. The site itself is located in a flat area of improved grassland. The land is very well draining and is generally amongst the driest of the COSMOS-UK sites.
SOIL_TEXTURE: LOAM TO CLAYEY LOAM, LOCALLY CHALKY

SITE_DESC: The Gisburn site is at the eastern edge of the Forest of Bowland above Stocks Reservoir in the headwaters of the River Hodder. The site is hosted by Forest Research. Within the footprint of the CRNS is a patchwork of conferious forest at different stages of growth. The site itself is located in an open area of rough grassland.

The Glensaugh Farm is run by the James Hutton Institute to provide facilities for agricultural and land use research. It is located at the southern edge of the Grampian Highlands. The farm is comprised of permanent pasture, improved pasture/arable, and semi-natural/moorland communities. The COSMOS-UK site is located on a south facing slope, within the last of these communities, in an area that is a complex patchwork of acid grassland and heather. The COSMOS-UK site at Glensaugh is the most northerly and highest within the network.

LOCATION_SOURCE: Site Info sheet on P drive
SITE_DESC: This site is located at an agricultural college farm to the north west of Hadlow. The field hosting the COSMOS-UK site is a grazed grassland on mineral soil.

STANDARD_LAYOUT: Site orientated at 45deg/315deg according to instructions from farmer. See CSL completion info for details.
SITE_DESC: The Holme Lacy site is based on the Holme Lacy College Pound Farm, which is an organic mixed farm in Herefordshire. The farm produces potatoes, wheat, oats, pea and barley mix, beans and cider apples as well as Hereford cattle and Lleyn sheep. The COSMOS-UK site is situated on a narrow buffer strip of rough grassland between two different crop fields.

Hartwood Home Farm is located near Shotts in Lanarkshire, in an area of upland farms devoted to stock rearing. The soils are heavy, poorly drained gleys typical of soils found in this part of central Scotland. High rainfall combined with poor drainage mean "poaching" is common especially from October to May. The site was previously managed by the James Hutton Institute and research was concerned with the development of sustainable management systems to meet agricultural and environmental objectives.
BEDROCK_CLASS: MUDSTONE, SILTSTONE, SANDSTONE, COAL, IRONSTONE AND FERRICRETE

LOCATION_SOURCE: Site Info sheet on P drive
STANDARD_LAYOUT: Forest flux tower. Platform height 32m. MetPak height 33m.
SITE_DESC: The Harwood site sits within the mature coniferous Harwood Forest which is managed by the Forestry Commission. Close to 90% of the forested area is Sitka spruce although current restocking proposals are to increase species diversity including native broadleaf planting. The COSMOS-UK site is co-located with a greenhouse gas flux monitoring tower operated by Forest Research.
BEDROCK_CLASS: LIMESTONE WITH SUBORDINATE SANDSTONE AND ARGILLACEOUS ROCKS

SITE_DESC: The Hillsborough site is located within the grounds of the Agri Food and Bio Sciences Institute (AFBI), County Down, Northern Ireland. AFBI carry out agri-food research and development for the Department of Agriculture and Environment and private companies. The COSMOS-UK site is located on flat, well-grazed grassland on a sandy loam.

The site at Hollin Hill is on a steep south facing slope in the Howardian Hills to the north-east of York. The steepness means that it departs from the ideal requirements for a COSMOS-UK site, but the site is interesting as a landslide observatory operated by the British Geological Survey. It is a grassland site on which sheep graze.

The Lizard is a Natural England National Nature Reserve (NNR), comprising wildlife rich heathland and coastline. The Lizard Peninsula hosts rare plants, invertebrates, and habitats with much of the area assigned as Sites of Special Scientific Interest. The COSMOS-UK site is situated on grassland on sandy soils. The site regularly ponds with water for extended periods after rain, before draining rapidly.

LOCATION_SOURCE: Site Info sheet on P drive
SITE_DESC: Loddington is the base of the Game and Wildlife Conservation Trust's Allerton Project which undertakes research on the effects of different farming methods on wildlife and the environment. The management of soil and water and 'Water Friendly Farming' is of particular interest to the project.  The clay soils of the farm are mainly used for arable crop production and in recent years there has been a move to reduced tillage and direct drilling.

Lullington Heath is in the rolling landscape of the South Downs between the villages of Litlington and Jevington and just a few kilometres inland from the Seven Sisters and Beachy Head. The site is hosted by Natural England within the Lullington Heath National Nature Reserve. The reserve is a patchwork of chalk grassland, perhaps the land cover most associated with the South Downs, valley grassland and chalk heath. The last of these is a combination of acid soil over alkaline chalk which supports plants loving both acid and alkaline conditions.

This site is hosted by the Morley Agricultural Foundation, a charity set up to support farming in the east of England through research and education. The farmed area is 300 ha of which about 90% are cropped. The farm undertakes field trials for a number of organisations at both field and plot scale. The COSMOS-UK site is located in a flat area on the boundary between two fields.
SOIL_TEXTURE: LOAM TO CLAYEY LOAM, LOCALLY CHALKY

SITE_DESC: Plynlimon is located at the northern end of the Cambrian Mountains in the headwaters of the River Wye. The Plynlimon area has hosted a range of environmental monitoring equipment since the 1960s. The soil has a high organic content supporting a semi-natural grassland vegetation.

This COSMOS-UK site is located at an MOD site near Salisbury. The monitoring site is located on uneven grassland where soils are highly calcareous mineral soils with lower lattice and bound water than that of a typical mineral soil.
